The concept of improving things and inventing something better doesn't have to be called perpetual motion. Making something more efficient is a noble thing to do and shouldn't be discouraged. The invention of ultralight aircraft of many types was done after airplanes were invented, and they work quite nicely. But 100 years ago they would have been considered faulty designs that would never work. In the same way devices can be developed that improve their efficiency. If inventors listened to the engineers of the day there would not have been cars or light bulbs.

The occasional visitor to my study still gets a kick out of seeing a couple of strings of coloured LEDs apparently being powered by a simple wire a few feet long strung around the study window (with a tuned circuit and earth connection present). Powered in fact by a local A.M.  talkback radio station whose transmitting mast is located about a mile away running at about 1MHz. Best use yet I've found for the hot air emitted in the studio. It only stops if the station is shutdown for maintenance and once get stopped by a lightning strike to the mast.

There are perpetual motion machines out there, but they're not something you can use to harvest energy. They're just curiosities, little conversation pieces you can have on your desk.

I recently saw a little desktop toy. It had a funnel and a curved ramp. You drop a ball bearing into the funnel, and it drops down onto a ramp that curves back around and launches the ball bearing back into that funnel to repeat the process, over and over. That is a perpetual motion machine. But it's just a toy; it's not something you can harvest energy from or anything.

You know, long ago before it was deemed impossible James Buoyant in the 1800’s made a machine that ran on buoyancy. They even coined the word buoyant from him. He created a perpetual motion machine that was very powerful. It’s turning was effected by the gravity of the sun and moon if that helps validate it’s probability. It had a sealed room around it and nobody got to see how it worked. The government, I think, didn’t believe him and he tore it to pieces. Fragments are all people got to see. I mean, if you cut a hole in the side of a fish tank and plug that hole with a wooden ball with an axle through it, one side is always trying to float and one side’s always trying to fall. The principles are there. Water is 8.8 pounds per gallon, very heavy. As we know water only rises to it’s own level, but if anything sits on top of the water it now goes higher than it’s own level. So, it would all drain on top of itself and that’s it. BUT, imagine you had a cylinder full of water and a straw out the bottom that goes to the top and "only rises to it’s own level. Then you you put this disc on top of the water so it’s like a piston and it’s weight pushes the water level up the small tube higher that it’s own level. This disc has a cylindrical shaped piece of styrofoam glued to it’s top so the disc and the cylindrical styrofoam piece look like a hat. Once the weight of the hat has pushed the water in the piston up the little tube and all of the water is now sitting mostly on the top of the hat you open a valve in the rim of the hat. The small body of water underneath the hat is "now connected" to the body of water above the hat and the now "one" body of water senses the hat is buoyant and the hat will rise through the one body of water. The valve need not be any more than a ballon thin hose that is pinched by 2 wheels. Close the valve in the rim of the hat and the small body of water on top of the hat becomes weight to push the hat down the piston once again and push the water on top of the hat as weight again. It’s the valve that turns the 2 bodies of water into one. The hat completely under the water floats upwards but the weight of the hat, plus the weight of the water filling up on top of the hat makes the water go up the tube and fall on top of the hat. Now, realistically, there would be too much friction in a piston but instead of a piston you could use a collapsable spring coated in balloon rubber. Now, if you did build one, out of say, a washer/dryer hose it should go up when you open the valve, and down when you close the valve. If it does do this then you have the basic principles for gravity and buoyancy to produce energy and make them have to re-write the laws of physics. Just a logical thought experiment. Feel free to prove it out. The cool part is that once you get it producing power by gravity you put it on an arm so it travels in a circle getting faster and faster. Centrifugal force outweighs gravity and the thing gets faster and stronger until it breaks into fragments. "Perpetual" in the context of a machine does not mean "for infinite time". Such a machine is not necessary because we will not exist for infinite time. Saying that it is simply impossible is short sighted. When the first flight was starting to be built everyone thought they were crazy and said it wouldn't work. Just because it hasn't been done doesn't make it impossible, just possibly improbable. Gravity is a seemingly never ending source of power that we still do not fully understand, but we don't call it impossible. The fact is that if we can figure out how to do one of 2 things a perpetual motion device is absolutely possible. Option 1 is we harness the power of gravity as a power source. Option 2 is that, since energy can not be created or destroyed, we would need to find an energy that we can use in both its natural state and its altered state so long as when the altered state is used it returns to the natural state or another state that can be used and eventually converted back to its natural state to create a closed loop of various energies. For the perpetual motion bird it is actual latent cooling that makes it work.  Same thing that makes you feel cold when you are wet.  The beak is wet and the warmer molecules evaporate which leaves the remaining cooler molecules behind.  That reduces the average temperature of the beak to the wet bulb temperature which is colder than the boiling point of the liquid inside the bird.  That causes the gas in the head of the bird to condense, which lowers the pressure drawing the rest of the liquid up making the head heavier so it dips again.  If the cup runs out of water, the evaporative cooling effect stops and the bird will stop.  So you are right it is heat that makes it work but heat in the water not in the room.  in a cold room it will work faster.  In a hot room it will stop.  it is driven by the cooling of the birds head caused by evaporation of the wet beak.

The Conservation of Energy, (Energy can neither be created nor destroyed) properly stated, possibly in question. Long ago, Sir Isaac wrote The Law of The Conservation of Matter. (Matter can neither be created nor destroyed) When Comb-o-Phobe Einstein and colleagues did their hot little thing, we got E=mc^2, aka Matter is one of many forms of energy, editing Newton's law to "Energy can neither be created nor destroyed."

Meanwhile, inside Bullwinkle's hat, some astrophysicists are looking at why the universe is not only expanding, but expanding faster all the time and giving serious consideration to dropping the Conservation of Energy as a necessary component to the explanation of an expanding universe. This is the tricky part. If the universe expanded any slower than it did, then it would have collapsed already. If the universe expanded any faster than it did, stars could not have formed (Knock-knock, Goldie Locks). Is it possible, Bullwinkle, the sum of energy in the universe is not a timeless constant? Others, maintaining the universe is all there is, might postulate that the original pre-big-bang ball loosed a form of energy (dark matter?) which has been mostly dormant (static/inactive) in the past and is more dynamic(active) in the present, pushing the stars ever faster. Personally, I do not think we have yet finished the final list of forms which Energy can take. Thus, Bullwinkle may pull a rabbit out of that hat, or something entirely not rabbit at all.

I certainly agree that any type of perpetual motion machine that claims to create energy out of nothing IS impossible. But, what if a wheel's design can somehow extract the energy associated with the masses of its active parts and output it to do useful work in the machine's environment? Such a wheel would not be able to run forever because it would eventually have outputted all of its onboard supply of energy. But, it might be able to run continuously, assuming no part failures, for millions of years! No not "perpetual" in the strictest sense of the word, but close enough for most practical purposes. Apparently, that is exactly what the "self moving" wheels of an early 18th century German - Polish inventor named Johann Bessler did. Here's a look at the mechanics he used in his wheels:

When I was in college, I knew it wasn't possible.  For whatever reason, after adulting for a while, I saw diagrams of machines that claimed to be be perpetual, and I believed it was possible.  For some reason.  What I find most interesting is that no matter how complex you make a perpetual wheel with moving parts that encourage more movement, the balance of the system is always such that friction or air resistance prevents it from increasing or keeping all of its energy for movement in an environment that introduces any friction or resistance at all, much less being able to draw any energy from it to power anything else.  So we'll just have to depend on what contributes energy into the system we have - the sun, or the heat from the earth.  Or whatever was deposited over eons before we came along and dug it up to use it as energy.

Well, the real answer is that perpetual motion machines aren't possible - as far as we've observed.

Our model of physics is still incomplete, and the law of conservation of energy could simply be a seemingly accurate approximation, or something with a hidden 'if' clause which we haven't discovered yet. Unless and until that happens, we should be scientists: trust that what we know about physics is correct, but at the same time do everything we can to prove ourselves wrong. If we blindly believe, we may pass up an opportunity which allows us to learn more.

Technically, there are perpetual motion machines.  The Earth will continue going around the sun for billions of years without any energy added to it.  And it is even possible to draw energy from that system without causing the Earth to stop moving or to fall into the sun.  A space craft can increase it's speed by a gravitational assist from the Earth.  But this doesn't violate any law of physics, because there is a difference between something that is perpetual in theory and what is perpetual in practice.  In theory, if you took enough kinetic energy from the Earth, it's orbit would deteriorate and it would fall into the sun.  But in practice it would never happen in any reasonable time scale.  So in practical terms, it's perpetual motion.  If you could figure out how to run a power plant off from it, you could supply our energy needs indefinitely.  So a real life perpetual motion machine would be something like that.  A system that has so much energy in it that it would be impossible to drain it in any reasonable time scale.  But such a machine would be a little larger than the currently proposed devices.  It would require engineering on a planetary scale.

We (our team) used a standard solved problem of physics, developed it further and draw a conclusion that, if considered as a heater, a standard water electrolysis process has efficiency/C.O.P. which is bigger than 1. We also show how to keep chemical and temperature neutrality. 
For your convenience I am citing the above link's text again. 
======================================
"Please have a look at the book "Solved Problems in Physics", 2004, Volume 2, p. 876, solved problem 12.97. The author of this book is Prof. S. L. Srivastava (Ph.D.)
The same book can be found at the link  https://books.google.bg/books?id=rrKFzLB9KQ8C&pg=PA876&lpg=PA876&dq=%22electrochemical+equivalent+of+hydrogen%22&source=bl&ots=tQ8PSMLet3&sig=ACfU3U2HOLB78XHl2o3q-JanapzSK-McJA&hl=bg&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjDpp2-zZXhAhWT5OAKHUfuBzUQ6AEwBHoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22electrochemical%20equivalent%20of%20hydrogen%22&f=false
--------------------------
For your convenience I am giving below the text of the problem and its solution.
--------------------------
12.97. In the electrolysis of sulphuric acid solution, 100 mg of hydrogen is liberated in a period of 20 minutes. The resistance of the electrolyte is 0.5 Ohm. Calculate the power consumed. Electrochemical equivalent of hydrogen is 1.044 x 10 -8 kg/C.
Solution: The power consumed is equal to 31.86 W.
-------------------------
PROF. S. L. SRIVASTAVA STOPS HERE HIS CALCULATIONS.
(The related solution's set of equations is not given here in order to save time and space. This set of equations however can be found in the book or in the link above.)
--------------------------
The above solved problem has a potential which can be developed further. And here it is. Here are our additional calculations.
1) Let us calculate the inlet energy, that is, inlet energy = (31.86 W) x (1200 s) = 38232 Ws = 38232 J.
2) Let us calculate the current I. The current I is given by I = (m)/(Z x t) = 7.9 A,
where
m = 0.0001kg of hydrogen
Z = electrochemical equivalent of hydrogen
t = 1200 s
3) The Joule's heat, generated in the process of electrolysis is given by
Q = I x I x R x t = (7.9 A) x (7.9 A) x (0.5 Ohm) x (1200 s) = 37446 J = outlet energy 1.
4) HHV of hydrogen is 142 000 000 J/kg. Therefore the heat H, generated by burning/exploding of 0.0001 kg of hydrogen, is given by
H = (142 000 000) x (0.0001) = 14200 J = outlet energy 2.
5) Therefore we can write down the equalities:
5A) outlet energy 1 + outlet energy 2 = 37446 J + 14200 J = 51646 J
5B) inlet energy = 38232 J.
6) Therefore COP is given by
COP = 51646 J/38232 J = 1.35  <=>  COP = 1.35  <=>  COP > 1.
------------------------------
Constant pure water and cooling agent supply could keep constant the electrolyte's temperature, heat exchange, mass and ohmic resistance, respectively.
Besides 0.0001 kg of hydrogen (and the related amount of the already split pure water) is small enough and can be neglected as a factor influencing the electrolyte's temperature, mass and ohmic resisitance.
-----------------------------
And one more interesting fact.
Literally the same solved problem can be found in an old Russian (still from the Soviet times) book "Сборник задач и вопросов по физике", 1986, p. 130, solved example problem 71. The authors of this book are Р. А. Гладкова and Н. И. Кутиловская. In the Russian version the data is a little different, that is, time is 25 minutes, the amount of generated hydrogen is 150 mg, Ohmic resisitance is 0.4 Ohm and the calculated power is 37 W.
Russians also stopped their calculations at 37 W.
Our further development of the Russian version led to COP = 1.37, that is, we have again COP > 1.
-----------------------------
Therefore the text above unambiguously shows that it is a matter of exact experimental data which is in perfect accordance with theory. Because I cannot imagine that three highly qualified experts in physics (yet strongly separated by time, space and nationality) would have made one and same mistake three times in a row. I think of it this way: Relative to everything, the universe is the one and only perpetual motion machine possible. No component of the universe can be one. Just the universe itself. When I try to think about arguments for and against the notion, my brain goes, (O.o). In a cartoonish way, I imagine time is both push and pull, meaning, if a PMM existed within the universe, the whole of existence would have to pause and wait for the final fate of its energy to be somehow “pre-calculated” before it could all move on. But it would never be pre-calculated, and the universe would be caught in an infinite loop. So the actual creation of a PMM would literally cause a universal veto; An instantaneous ripple across the universe and back, which would destroy the PMM as promptly as the moment before it existed. That means, if you make a machine that suddenly self-destructs on its debut run, and everyone decides to have a laugh, just own the moment and say, “I must’ve created a perpetual motion machine. Wow. Vetoed by Mother Universe herself. What an honor.” ;^} -Phill, Las Vegas

The indisputable truth about so called, Free Energy.

🔴 First, there is no such thing as Free Energy, because everything has an associated cost attached to it. Rather the term implies no more monthly electric bill.

🔴 Free Energy was a term created in the 1970s to promote alternative energy resources.

🔴 Wind, solar, hydroelectric, and thermal are all prime examples of Free Energy after start up costs. However, over time, there will eventually be maintenance cost.

🔴 Unbeknownst to most, some 90% of all man made generated electricity incorporates magnetisum.

By considering Thermodynamics laws, perpetual motion machines are not possible in real time. Thermodynamic first law says that "Energy cannot be created nor destroyed". Perpetual motion machines creates energy which is not possible. Thermodynamic 2nd law says that "Energy is means to be spread out" so that heat generates in the machine at one point which makes the machine stop working. So, perpetual motion machines are not possible in real time.

Nice video. Couple of personal opinions I have on perpetual motion... First off, the laws of physics are disputable based on the amount of information we have. At this point in humanities maturity cycle- most of what we know is fairly conceptual. Not to say that I don't agree with them for the most part, but I think it's important to continually look outside the box the way our predecessors did when they established the laws or "concepts" we have today. There are plenty of occurrences throughout the world and history where the laws of physics a proven to be failable. Again, not that I don't agree with their foundations... I just personally don't think in terms of "this is not possible". Second, in regards to renewable energy, am I the only person still seeing a viable gain here? Sure the Bhaskara's wheel may not be perpetual motion in its truest form but working models still show that the wheel will, in fact, spin longer on its own momentum and weight displacement than the initial force used to initiate the spin that set it in motion. My point here is that it is, in fact, likely possible that energy could be derived using these attempts at the perpetual motion that only require periodic "kick-starts" so to speak. Could not a scaled up model using contemporary technologies to minimize friction and computer calculated weight displacement increase the returns as far as the duration of wheel spin to a point that someone could simply just give it a nudge every few days or something to keep the cycle going in order to generate electricity? Maybe I'm just stoned and watching too many TED talks again...

THIS IS WRONG. Our entire *EXISTENCE* relies on, and REQUIRES, perpetual motion machines.

EXAMPLE:
- a block of iron weighing 10 pounds was found in an old Egyptian tomb from the year 2500 b.c., covered in mummy preservatives so it didn't rust
- that makes the block of iron 4518 years old at least.
- how much longer will that 10 pound iron block stay togther as a block? AS LONG AS IT'S KEPT from rusting.


*CONSIDER ONE ATOM OF IRON* from that 10 pound block. It has 26 protons, 26 electrons, and 30 neutrons (see www.ptable.com). Atomic symbol for Iron is "Fe"

- each constituent part of that single Iron atom has energy -- the neutrons and protons have angular momentum. The electrons have angular momentum and orbital angular momentum. There are 26 electrons spread among 4 electron shells humming around that atom's nucleus as a standing wave.

- And that one atom is linked in a lattice to other iron atoms that in total make up the 10 lb. block of iron -- they 'stick together' through ionic/metallic bonding.

Consider this. E=mc^2. So how much energy "E" is in a 10lb block of iron? QUITE OF BIT OF ENERGY. But how is that possible, since the constituent parts of all the Iron atoms in the block should be losing energy as they vibrate in the lattice and experience angular and orbital momentum and spin. What allows all those atoms to keep all that E=mc^2 energy?

ATOMS ARE PERPETUAL MOTION MACHINES.

The proof is this. If an atom of Iron could lose all its energy = in other words, set "E" to zero in the E=mc^2 formula --

-- so you have 0 = mc^2. But "c" is a constant (it's the speed of light) and cannot go to zero. Thus, the mass "m" must go to zero if 0 = mc^2, if the iron atom loses all its energy.

Now consider the 10 lb. block of Iron -- set "E" to zero in E=mc^2: 0 = mc^2.
If the 10 lb block of iron loses all its energy IT HAS TO DISSOLVE INTO THIN AIR, its mass must fall to zero => 0 = 0c^2 = 0.

ATOMS DO NOT LOSE THEIR ENERGY "E". We found a 4518-year-old block of Iron in an Egyptian tomb. It hasn't lost any energy "E" in all that time.

Now, 4518 years may not be "perpetual" but that block of Iron will be here a very, very long time.

ATOMS ARE PERPETUAL MOTION MACHINES.

And if they weren't, we would have all dissolved a long time ago. How much energy does your body have? E = mc^2. If the atoms of your body lose all their energy -- WHICH THEY SHOULD if "there is no perpetual motion" IS TRUE --

-- then your body's energy "E" would be zero, 0 = mc^2
So your MASS m must go to zero too.

Your car, your grandma, your dog, your house = THEY ARE ALL in existence DUE TO PERPETUAL MOTION.

I've had my go at Perpetual motion machines, never got a working one but at least mine span a few time before stopping. This host can't even get hers to spin once. Nothing is for free and that's true - that's why you change your design so you are focusing on improving an existing energy rather than trying to have opposing forces and yet expect a result that cannot occur with equal opposing forces. You can't get something from nothing but you can bring something back that you didn't have by creating receptors to catch what is already there.

Antennas, Solar cells etc - these will always be the path of least resistance in regards to easy energy because the energy already exists - you just have to create something that can conduct with the energy and then connect the conductor to a battery. For example: You can create small antennas to catch 5G energy, setup kinetic rods inside balloon batons to convert wind energy into kinetic energy, you an take advantage of river currents, you can create small batteries out of citrus fruit etc etc, there are lots of ways to get energy from nature. Nature already is moving everywhere so rather than try to create a perpetual motor - take advantage of the perpetually moving nature.

The real interest in perpetual motion machines is that we know they will never work. And this is great because it gives us a base-line. Now, what is good about these useless devices is that we can make improvements to the designs until they have less friction than the last, or if they have a non-symmetrical weight distribution across the axle - these are ways you can mitigate resistance and thereby increase the number of times they cycle. So why are these important? Because they are ways of making motion more efficient and can be applied to actual mechanisms that we do use, such as car engines and axles, windmills etc where the focus is on increasing efficiency.
So to summarize -for all those low IQbies, perpetual motion will not exist however they can be used as control systems to compare to modified systems so we can work out ways to make mechanics more efficient.

My point is that the laws of Physics are based on data we have collected to this point. What too many people don't understand, is that there is so much more out there (undefinably so) that we aren't taking into consideration, that to assume our text books know it all is a complete fallacy.

Not to say that what we have learned is false, but that what we have learned is only part of the whole picture... A very small part.

I've got a back-ground in physics / engineering. And, I've been thinking about perpetual motion a LOT lately. I find it hard to believe, nay, I find it IMPOSSIBLE to believe, that NOBODY has developed a perpetual motion engine using a buoyancy force & gravity. (Well, maybe it wouldn't be considered perpetual because it would need to be refilled with water, but that's it.) Meaning, let's say I put 100 ping-pong balls in a fish-tank, then I put a thin layer of sturdy plastic over the ping-pong balls, if I were to hold them under-water with my finger, it would be pressing upwards with a certain amount of Newtons. So, that's energy source one, a buoyant force infinitely pressing upwards (assuming you refill with water.) However, it would have to be very balanced, because once the ping-pong balls reach the TOP of the water, then the potential buoyant force is gone. But, whilst they are submerged it's a nearly infinite amount of force.Then, you have another infinite force, gravity, pushing DOWNWARDS, the opposite direction. So, for example, you could use the buoyancy force to press two magnets closer together than they would be other-wise. And, this could be used in various ways. I just don't understand how NOBODY has developed CLEAN energy with buoyancy & gravity alone.

To be a trifle more accurate, the bird keeps going because the air in the room is NOT saturated with water. It is the difference between the partial vapor pressure of water in the air compared to the vapor pressure of the water. If you put the bird into an air-tight box, it will continue to work as the water evaporates UNTIL the air in the box becomes saturated. Then it will stop.

During my time in college studying aerospace engineering, I was told only ONE story that REALLY stuck in my mind after all these years.  One engineering professor stated that "back in the day" before supersonic jets, it was declared IMPOSSIBLE to fly faster than the speed of sound.  Seriously. All kinds of proofs were created to emphasize this impossibility, too. They stated that MANY have tried it before, but it's "impossible", and many laughed at those continuing to try. Equations were built to "prove" that it "COULDN'T POSSIBLY be done"....Until it was.   Oh and yeah, then suddenly every university could figure out why it COULD be done... ahhh, so easy to see now.  There are so MANY examples of how the many naysayers are blinded by supposed "scientific proof". But ultimately, a "proof" is only good until the day it is disproven. That's what's wickedly cool about TRUE SCIENCE.  Oh, and simply naming these devices as "perpetual motion machines" is a way to get the skeptical onto the Impossibility Bandwagon which, I believe, will be proven to be wrong. We certainly do NOT know all there is to know about our universe and we are still baffled my much, and still surprised. I'd like to think that enough of us with open minds can create what those with a close mind can't. Let's just do it.

Sure... that one is easy... build a big vacuum chamber as a tower... siphon water to the top of a tank atop the vacuum chamber/tower... at the vacuum port is the control valve (gate type). Inside the tank the water is drawn into the bottom of a bag that's checked one way (intake). The exhaust, also at the bottom of the bag, is checked one way to the turbine. The intake is larger than the exhaust. air is allowed in and out of the tank but not into the bag. open the control valve water level rises in the bag. close the valve before the water enters the vacuum port... the bag collapses, water runs into the turbine. Don't forget that you will need a baffle between the water intake and the vacuum port (a pipe with holes drilled in it). The baffle is there to make sure water rises evenly into the bag in the tower. To sum it up, basically by combining the principle that nature abhors a vacuum and will seek to fill it and gravity, perpetual motion can be achieved.

The question "Are perpetual motion machines possible?" can be answered with a simple yes but the part where the confusion comes from is when you say "no energy input".
Your example of the Drinking bird shows that perpetual motion is possible: it will continue in perpetuity. Even although the structure of the system will eventually break down as its made of glass, if replaced, will drink forever (theoretically). So, if we made a machine using 64 birds (as an example) and replaced the ones that broke down, the entire system should never break down, itll just become 63/64ths as powerful until the fault is fixed.
The point to a perpetual motion machine is that "we" dont put in more energy than we get out. This can be looked at from two different sides though.
1) Are we physically adding energy to the system? ie are we expending our own energy (ie thats pointless) or,
thanks to the fundamental laws of physics regarding air pressure etc
2) are we getting energy out where we dont have to physically input any?
Yes, a perpetual motion machine that takes in no energy but outputs anything more than abolutely 0 energy is (probably) impossible (and is definitely impossible with our current tech) but that isnt the goal. The goal is to make use of these systems that surround us anyway and get that to create energy and basically do the work for us. We (people) are effectively inputting 0 energy but energy is still coming out that could be usable by us.
The 2nd most recent state of energy production was to use coal, gas and nuclear. These came with problems though 1) coal and gas isnt going to last more than a few hundred years 2) it needs to be taken out the ground, processed and transported. Hence why these types of energy are expensive.
The newest state is using wind and water power. "We" arent putting any energy in (after installation) but we are getting energy out. Transportation is still an issue with these, or at least for the decent versions that could power a home for example. Basically, these things are huge.
The newest/next step is to be able to create cheap and efficient energy that is easily portable. So called "perpetual motion" systems could do this if we could simply look beyond the silly and completely pointless mis-understanding of where the input energy is coming from.

Your description of the drinking bird doesn't match with my understanding.  The toy works best in warm, low humidity weather with the water and surrounding air at thermal equilibrium.  When the bird is upright, water in the felt-like bird head evaporates, cooling the head to a temperature lower than the ambient temperature of the bulb at the opposite end.  By the ideal gas law, that causes a lower pressure in the head, drawing the liquid up.  When the bird tips and the beak touches the water, the head warms back up to the ambient temperature, which increases the temperature in the head and forces the liquid back down, causing the bird to quickly stand back upright.  Leaning over is a slow process.  Standing back upright is a fast process.

For a machine to move in some manner perpetually, it would require two factors at work:

1: A steady loophole in which energy is transferred between machine components in a circular process, with energy traveling from Piece A to Piece B to Piece C, and so on throughout a number of "n" pieces until energy is transferred back to Piece A in the same quantity that it left Piece A

2: The machine's constituent particles, which in our case would most likely be baryonic matter, would have to be 100% stable in order to sustain an endless mechanical process. No known particle can do this

The oxford electric bell has ran continuously for over 170 years. I'm not saying that it is a perpetual motion machine (we know it must stop we just don't know when). But this demonstrates a problem with the concept that goes beyond physics. That being if you had a perpetual motion machine how would you know? In order to prove itself it would have to run continuously under ideal conditions literally forever.

Even if you have something that should at least in theory run forever. Something that truly bends or breaks the rules as we know them (and having it would actually change what we know). There would be that nagging feeling that it may for some reason inexplicably stop. As inexplicable as it must be in order to be thought of as a true perpetual motion machine to begin with.

But we don't need perpetual motion. We just need near perpetual motion. Something that gives us a lot more energy out than energy put in. Or something that works so well passively (say off of room temperature and temperature differences or perhaps even the background radiation of the universe) that it might as well be perpetual motion for all practical purposes.

Perpetual motion machines are impossible, but the reason is never friction. The reason behind the unbalanced wheel is that, while there is more weight on one side of the wheel, there weight on the other side of the wheel is distributed further away from the center. The further away the weight is from the point around which it rotates, the less force it takes to rotate it. In the end, the effective force on the entire wheel comes to an equilibrium. That's the real explanation, and not friction, because friction can be reduced or overcome.
You also have to consider the eventual decay of any perpetual motion machine that we build. So that raises another question...Can we build a contraption that will stand the test of time?

This isn't all that clear an explanation. People in the comments below keep talking about 'the laws of physics' and 'thermodynamics' but that's needlessly theoretical. The overbalanced wheel isn't doing anything different from any ordinary wheel. Yes, it's kind of true that the wheel of an upside down bike won't just start turning on its own "because of the laws of thermodynamics" but the more intuitive explanation is simply that there are no unbalanced forces acting on it. There's nothing to make it turn. If you sum up all the forces creating torques, they add up to zero. The movement of the parts that move - the sliding coins, the sloshing water - is distracting, but all they do is move around. In the overbalanced wheel set-up, the idea is that leverage will create a larger moment on one side than the other. This is the result of the coin with the longer moment arm - the greater leverage - falling further than the coin closer to the axis. It uses more of its potential than it gives back to the coin that is being lifted. That means the coin being lifted doesn't gain back the potential it will need when its turn comes to do the same job. Having more coins moving around masks this balance, but you can't make energy from 3-card monte.

In simple terms, the overbalanced wheel relies on the intuition that a teeter totter 'creates energy'. The person sitting further out can lift the person sitting closer in. But once the person out at the end hits the ground, he can't get closer to the center without climbing, and the person up in the air can't get further out on the beam without also climbing. After they've both invested this energy then it's ready to do work again. In the overbalanced wheel the motions and work of lifting the falling coins from their 'expended' positions back to their 'potential' positions is hidden by spurious hand-waving. But the physics of the system is no more complicated than it is in a piece of plywood nailed to a wall. There are no unbalanced forces at work. It's a static system.

Confusing energy and forces leads to non-sensical ideas such as free energy (perpetual motion) machines. Such machines always fail precisely because forces are not energy, and you can't extract one single bit of energy from a force itself. For instance, a "free energy" machine could consist of a ball that rolls down a hill and hits a paddle, which turns a wheel. The problem with this machine is that the ball has to be returned to the top of the hill for the process to continue, and the amount of energy you have to put into your machine to put the ball back at the top of the hill equals the energy you get out of your machine from the spinning wheel. Actually, the amount of energy you get out of your machines is always less than the energy you put into it because some of the inputted energy is wasted to heat energy through friction. Free energy proponents devise ever cleverer ways to get the ball back to the top of the hill (or the magnets separated again, or the rubber band stretched again, etc.), hoping that just one more extra gear or wheel will somehow magically create energy out of nothing. But they can never get around the fact that forces are not energy and you can never get more energy out of a system than you put in.

What about hydroelectric plants that extract energy from the falling water in rivers? Don't they extract energy from gravity for free? No. The water in the river is no different from the ball that you have to haul up the hill. The water got its energy not from gravity but from some external agent that placed it high up in the mountains against gravity, so it could fall down the river bed. The external agent in this case is sunlight. Sunlight warms the ocean, causing the water to evaporate and float into the sky. The energy contained in the photons of sunlight is converted to the potential energy of the water molecules that are lifted high in the sky. These water molecules then rain down to the ground, form rivers, and flow back down to the ocean, converting their potential energy to kinetic energy, heat, and (in a hydroeletric plant) electricity. Ultimately, therefore, hydroelectric plants extract solar energy from water.

comment_text: So, at 3:26, if something is called perpetual motion machine, then this implies that it can't be explained how it works, because it doesn't use any Laws of Physics, and thus does not work outside of fraud or trickery. Instead, it uses hyperbole by its creator or promoter to make up for solid analysis? So, all I have to do, or anyone else for that matter, is be able to explain why something "appears" to be a perpetual motion machine, but actually isn't, merely because it doesn't defy any Law of Physics (such as the Dunking Bird example), because it can readily be explained in terms we already know from having studied Physics, Thermodynamics, Electrical Engineering, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, etc? So, this use of the term: "perpetual motion machine", by Physics Girl, helps me to understand why so often this term is used in my face by (sometimes) not very friendly people whose patience has worn so thin, that any discussion of "apparent" perpetual motion machines never gets started, or maintained for very long, simply because no one has thoroughly, nor accurately, analyzed any candidate machine for either debunking it or explaining it - and so, consequentially, it does not exist as a true machine, but merely exists as an artistry of magic and imagination? Whew! I feel much better, now, because I understand that just because some machine is called "perpetual motion" does not make it so. In fact, it is our collective misuse of language that perpetrates this dilemma. So long as a machine can't be explained, so long is it a candidate for perpetual machine, but still not yet a perpetual motion machine. In other words, a non-perpetual motion machine is a definitive machine while a perpetual motion machine is not. All we've managed to do is define what a machine is and exclude everything else which lies outside of our collective ability to define. Perpetual motion machine's only flaw is that it has yet to graduate to the status of a true machine and specific instances of "apparent" perpetual motion have yet to be explained. Well, it's back to the drawing boards and study of basic and advanced theory...

The problematic idea many struggle with is 1N in equals 1N out! If you can get 1.01N out then 1% can be used for useful work. Sadly 1N is usually only at best ~0.95N out. That missing ~5% was given to its motion (the inflation of time space ). Conversion is what we currently call efficiency of motion (with very little friction): 0.01% to 99.99% -- or: E=MC^2. E is not equal to M times C to infinity to avoid faster than light transmission! Why? Because space tells time when to move (not the mass of the object: hence the possibility of wormholes and warp drives)!

In short: at rest mass or not! Newton has a law covering this.

Example: a weight spaced on a gravity wheel will always find its equilibrium in time (yet the number of revolutions can be infinite due to chaos theory). However: any work obtained must not assist that ultimate goal (so: no damping or quantum jumps).

Is leverage a form of free energy?  Try to lift your car when you have a flat tire by yourself.  Can't be done.  Now get your jack out and like magic you can now lift your car.  It's called leverage.  Can you run 20 miles an hour?  No, probably not. However, get on your bike and peddle really fast and I bet you can now go about 20 miles an hour on a flat surface.  The bike doesn't have any energy of it's own but it enables you to go faster than you could by yourself.  So, you are able to go faster than you could if you were simply running by doing nothing more than riding your bike.  The bike doesn't have any outside power sources except your peddle power...  Yet the bike enables you to leverage your own personal power to go faster than you could on your own.  So, you are able to go further and faster without using any additional energy.  Right?  So, if this is true then every time you use a jack to lift your car or ride a bike to go faster than you could by running or walking you are in violation of the so called Law of Conservation of Energy.

Whether perpetual motion is impossible or not really depends on your definition. If you definite it as creating new energy, of course not, but if you define it as something going forever without the input of new energy, that is possible. Something will go forever until a outside force works to change it, it is another basic law of physics. So all you would need to do is remove all interference of motion and something can go forever. Like a wheel on a absolute frictionless axes in a true vacuum environment could spin forever. Now how such could be created would be incredibly hard and probably outside of current technology. And of course would only serve as a novelty anyway. No work could be created because any attempt to harvest work would work against the momentum.

Another example of a perpetual motion "machine" that we can actually do is, shooting anything into space. It will continue to go forever till it reaches gravitational or physical interference. Another might be, anything in orbit, if the distance is right, should continue to orbit forever till something interferes with said orbit. So many of the moons and planets in our solar system are quasi perpetual motion. Of course once our sun goes red giant, that would probably change.

Silly people! Designing a perpetual motion machine is EASY!!!

You just need to build a wheel out of a material that will never outgas any particles. Now build a container slightly larger than the wheel out of the same material. The container should be able to be closed with a perfect airtight seal. It also needs to have some controls embedded in it that will allow you to manipulate objects inside.

Put the wheel in the container and before sealing the container suck all the air out, leaving a perfect vacuum. Now take the container to deep space, outside of any gravity field. Position the wheel carefully in the center of the container so that no part of it is touching the container and start the wheel spinning. You must impart rotational motion only, with no lateral motion.

Now sit back. Without any friction present the wheel will continue to move perpetually. You have a perpetual motion machine. Now i realize that the engineering challenges involved in actually building this device are pretty serious, but the theoretical design is incredibly simple.

Slight error with your Ideal Gas Law: the constant you should be using is 'R' (the Universal Gas Constant, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas_constant ), and not 'k' (the Boltzmann Constant, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boltzmann_constant ), and so it should look like this: pV=nRT. If you really want to use k, you can, but then you have to change your n (number of mols) by the Avogadro constant (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avogadro_constant )

By the definition of "getting something for nothing," perpetual motion is impossible. But ideally, perpetual motion would be about a transfer of kinetic energy and potential energy which would create self-sustained motion. For instance, the idea behind the quarter wheel (though it doesn't work), is that the kinetic energy created via the motion of the quarter would transfer to the wheel when said wheel was the acting force to stop it. The next quarter would do the same, then the next, and so on. In short, perpetual motion isn't about getting something for nothing, but rather for a transfer of energies to reach a point of self-sustainability.

I have been working on an application for "pseudo-perpetual motion machines-" how do we get objects that use ubiquitous forces and forms of energy exerted by or present on Earth to do work in a useful way for generating electricity? Years ago, I thought of improving a magnetic propulsion circle whose major problem was that the loop could not be closed by building the circle on a very slight incline, and letting gravity close the loop. I was 10 years old at the time, and today (about 10 years later) I don't think that idea would work. However, I think the spirit of the idea is useful. The drinking bird is a classic example of a 'pseudo-perpetual motion machine,' which will continually reorient itself under standard conditions, as long as there is water in the cup. What if that bird were adapted to generate energy in places where it is unlikely to stop moving for lengthy amounts of time? Well, then, you'd have a 'prolonged motion' machine, and you would get work with no human input beyond building the device. And if we don't have to provide the input, then it really is like getting something from nothing. Photovoltaic cells and catalytic water splitters (like the 'artificial leaf') operate on a similar principle, but uses the 'useful energy' of light. We tend to think of ambient heat as 'useless energy of the surroundings' in physics, and so I think it would be a really good idea to see if we could exploit this ubiquitous particle motion and the pressure it exerts. After all, we have no matter that is has no heat energy.

4:17 Actually there is no such thing as "The Law of Conservation of Energy". Really it is an assumption we bring in when appropriate in physics in our calculations, but in general it comes as a result of some symmetry in time generally or some consideration of potential or force. In quantum mechanics the system is not always in the same energy state. If you make successive measurements of energy sure. The state only differs from an energy eigenstate by a fase, but if you make a measurement of position on a particle of definite energy the wave function collapses into a position eigenstate which is an infinite superposition of energy eigenstates. It really isn't something that we consider a fundamental property in physics in general.

Solar and wind are essentially free, yet we still use fossil fuels.

The "freeness" of an energy source has little to do with whether or not we will use it. It always boils down to intrinsic thermodynamic advantages, specifically energy density, specificity, and reliability.

Even if perpetual motion existed, unless it leads to energy systems that have a clear advantage over current energy systems in terms of power density and so on, using the "free" energy will literally make you slower than everyone else.
What happens when you run faster than you fall in two opposing directions, but you keep switching direction? Or your center of gravity keeps turning inside out?

She repeats a common misconception about the unbalanced wheel, that kind of device was never ment to produce energy out of nothing, it was ment to harness the perpetual energy flux of gravity, just like a windmill harnesses the energy of the wind, or a watermill harnesses the energy of flowing water. The problem is, gravity is acting upon the entire body of the device, you can not isolate gravity to make it act just upon one side of the device, so inventors have tried to come up with a way that continuously isolates the load on one side of the device. Unfortunately all known designs are the same, and they do not manage to isolate the load on one side. That does't prove that such mechanism is impossible, it only proves that there is no known working configuration of the mechanism. It might be imposible or it might not, either way, we are not talking about energy creation but about energy harnessing.

I love the term "in theory." What it really means is, "I don't know the theory."
There is a wonderful word, entropy, that physicists both love and hate. It is the reason that nothing is forever -NOTHING. But it's also the reason that we can use energy at all. ALL energy we use is the result of entropy.

In a nutshell, entropy can be stated as energy will always move from a state of higher energy to a state of lower energy. Period. You can slow it or change its form in some cases, but you can never stop it. Heat dissipates to cold. Light emanates to darkness, or is attenuated to heat. The thing that is up high, falls down. Complex chemical compounds decay into simpler compounds, giving off radiation, expansion or heat (or all). Large atoms decay into smaller atoms, until they stabilize.

The only time energy is not moving from high to low, is where everything is equal. At that point, for all practical purposes, there is no more energy. There is a great old scifi story about this, I think by Asimov. I wish I could remember the title, but it is about man's search for a way to reverse entropy. Not to spoil the story for those of you that might read it, but the end explains the beginning, and gives a nod toward the futility of opposing entropy.

On the other hand, we can be thankful for entropy. Entropy is the reason that the complex nitrogen/carbon compounds in wood like to combine with oxygen in a reaction that gives off light and heat (we call this fire). Entropy is the reason that the hydrocarbons in your gas tank let you take your favorite girl to cruise night. Entropy is even the reason that electrons move through conductors to do the myriad wonderful things that our modern world takes for granted.

SO the very thing that will eventually cause everything to stop, is also the only reason that anything is moving in the first place.

Not exactly a perpetual motion machine, but consider the following system.
A fast- rotating asteroid rotates every few hours. it's not rotating fast enough to spin itself apart, but it is fast enough that a stationary orbit is relatively low.

I cleverly put a rigid tube extending up from the asteroid to above stationary orbit, such that the tip of the tube greatly exceeds escape velocity.

I then begin feeding a long chain up the tube, with the centripetal acceleration at the top of the chain eventually beginning to drag the chain up the tube. The chain it's arbitrarily long, and it's attached to a winch at the bottom which turns and generates power by braking the chain's acceleration.

If this can't work, explain why. If this can work, explain where the energy comes from to put the chain on an escape trajectory.

Assume the chain has high enough tensile strength to do this and it's of uniform thickness.

All well and good, but I would like to see you conduct the following experiment. You will need: 1 computer cooling fan with 7 blades, and 8 neodymium magnets.

Glue 7 of the magnets to the blades of the fan, taking care to make sure that the positive pole of each of the magnets is facing outward. Once you have that set up, place your remaining magnet, with the positive pole toward blades, on the edge of the fan.

What should happen, if done correctly, is the fan should spin freely, with seemingly no input.

Let me stress something for the doubters: this is NOT a perpetual motion engine; it's a magnetic repulsion engine. It functions by the consistent repulsive force of like (as in, not opposite) magnetic poles. And, although it will take an incredibly long time, the magnets will eventually depolarize and the engine will cease to function. But, "like" a perpetual motion engine, the system require no further input of fuel once the magnets are in place.

"It's impossible" - I am not comfortable with saying anything is "impossible" after us as humans for millennium have claimed many things to be "impossible" when today they aren't. I would prefer to say "The current known laws of physics do not allow perpetual motion machines"

Note, this doesn't mean there are pm-machines out there, it simply leaves the possibility that there are.

And bringing out the conservation of energy card isn't so concrete when you look at the universe... The universe has lots of energy but from what we can tell, before the big bang, there was literally nothing (or at least no time and no space, thus no energy). Similarly we know that particles can pop in and out of existence (virtual particles). So energy can come from "nothing" it just has to be returned and cannot be used.

The final thing I would like to note is many old laws have been overthrown at some point. Newton's laws of motion was overthrown with Einstein's Laws of motion. Recently the laws of momentum have been proven non-universal by the EMDrive. I wouldn't be surprised if we find ways around the Law of the conservation of energy some day.

The problem with perpetual motion is you will always put more energy in than you get out of it. We have created some really efficient devices that spin for a very long time, but if we were to use their spin to create energy, we would still find it generates less energy than was used to spin it.

The other problem is once you try to tap energy from any spinning motion machine, it will slow down because you are literally stealing energy from it. Even if we were able to overcome friction, the issue would still be there because friction is what causes/transfers the energy in the first place. If you were to transfer energy another way, it would still result in a loss of total energy from the machine. This is why even in the vacuum of space and in a zero gravity environment, you still wouldn't be able to make perpetual motion. So not only does a perpetual motion device need to produce energy, it needs to produce more energy than it takes for it to spin in the first place.

But if we were able to bend some rules, we would be able to essentially create perpetual motion. If we were to for example, be able to reverse or remove gravity in a localized field, we could use that to keep a wheel spinning like a waterfall. Of course, if the energy it takes to do that is greater than the energy we get from the wheel, then we're back to square one. Just like if reversing or removing gravity to put things in orbit cost more energy than simply using a rocket, we just wouldn't do it....unless it was for safety reasons.

Any perpetual motion machine would need to be made of 2 types of exotic matter with specific properties that isn't known to exist, this way you won't have to actually put any real energy into keeping the system going since it will be a purely matter vs matter reaction.


If we were able to exploit radiation pressure or particles popping in and out of existence to add to the power of a perpetual motion device, it could also be possible to create a device that fits in the laws of physics; it wouldn't really be a perpetual motion machine, it would just be a machine getting a push from ambient energy in the universe, which is for all intents and purposes, infinite......even if it wasn't, there's soo much energy there just waiting to be tapped into that we couldn't use even a fraction of it even if we became a massive civilization powered entirely by it.

According to Thermodynamics, nothing creates energy, it is finite and moves from place to place, and work is a result of tapping the energy flow.  So the real question is can you alternate source and sink with no or little losses over time.  This is not the same as maximizing work output in a single cycle and dumping the energy, that is described by Carnot and in such a case you wish to maximize the temperature difference. This is more like a heat pump where you want to minimize the temp difference to maximize efficiency and or lower losses, as the lower the differences, the slower the signal frequency and travel.  Such that you alternate heat source and sink, in a manner than seems continuous but is discrete on each half of the cycle as the material heats up and cools down, but provided source temp is not greater than environment, then energy is maintained within the system.  Why because at the surface of the device temp would be the same as environment.

By definition, a perpetual motion system does not claim to create energy... only to conserve it... thus the perpetual motion. It takes an input energy and, if properly isolated from all external factors, it would, in theory preserve that energy. I find this video misleading since it claims that perpetual motion systems are meant to create energy.

The laws of thermodynamics are well established such that in the true sense you cannot build a perpetual motion machine! But working with nature you can come close for all practical purposes, and the key is understanding chemical kinetics and natural oscillators, and what work is and is not. Work is deformation of matter overtime, it is not energy, it is the result of energy transfer. What this means is that you can never have more work done by a system than energy flowing through it.  However you can have paired chemical oscillators which transfer energy back and forth which are constrained from reaching equilibrium. Like an atom where the atoms electron and nucleus pass photons back and forth. Another way to look at it is as two thermal batteries which double and half in equilibrium pressure with a 15K Delta, and in which absorbing is exothermic and releasing is endothermic, and you have two pairs of these thermal batteries where they transfer energy among themselves. As long as they operate at ambient temperature conditions and never get at a higher temperature the energy is constrained within the system, and the batteries provide temperature drop but the signal cannot travel any further than the opposed thermal battery to get the energy. It's a regenerative heat engine. Instead of discarding the thermal energy the heat source and sink oscillate. Is it perpetual? No! It will wear out and break down, and its also dependent on local temperature to constrain it.  The higher that local temp and the greater the chemical reaction to absorbing and releasing the more work can be performed, but work will always be less than the energy flow. However chemical oscillators  can work over hundreds of years, and it is much more efficient.  Carnot should be called work to energy flow efficiency because that is what it measures over a single cycle.  Overtime, if we can oscillate the temperature difference and not go above the ambient temp as heat source, then we can constrain the energy flow within a system, and it will continue to do work.  This is all acceptable within the framework of thermodynamics.

The three Laws of thermodynamic:
1.- You cannot win. For any energy invested in a system, you can't obtain more than its equivalent in work and heath in a given system.
2.- You cannot tie. In any given system, the hotter parts cannot maintain their temperature and will invariably get colder, until the total temperature averages.
3.- You cannot stop playing. No matter the system, the minimum temperature is absolute zero. If our universe can be considered a closed system, the far, far, faaaaaaaaaaaar future is a cold and lonely place.

In order to achieve motion in a machine, some type of potential energy has to be changed into kinetic energy to create movement in the machine.  There is no perfectly efficient means of doing so.  More energy has to be added to the machine than is experienced as kinetic energy because of the depletion of energy in the system as heat due to friction within the machine and between the machine and its surroundings, i.e. air or water drag.  For this reason alone, perpetual motion is not possible.

To clarify there are 3 types of PPMs (perpetual motion machines) This video was about type 1 (a device that produces work without input) primarily.

Types 2&3 don't violate the conservation of energy.

Type 2 uses thermal energy without a gradient or heats a working fluid when the fluid is at equilibrium with the environment. This violates the 2nd law of thermal dynamics, the entropy content of a closed system can never go down. That said this is a statistical law not an absolute one.

Type 3 are the most possible even if they are still impossible. A type 3 PPM is just an object that will continuously move forever, But you have to run down a list of things to slow the object and eliminate them. It starts with friction, then electromagnetism, then energy loss due to radiation, QM effects, and finally gravity waves. But if you can do that you can have a top spin forever. . . in it's own universe with nothing to stop it.

Your explanation for the drinking bird was incorrect. Partially correct.

The water is at the same temperature as the bird, so the beak doesn't cool down because it touches water.

The beak cools down because it's wet. As water evaporates from the beak, the beak cools down - remember that evaporation takes energy! As the beak cools down, it cools down the head and the gas inside shrinks. That liquid rises until the bird becomes top-heavy.

The water bowl is there to re-wet the beak, so evaporation can continue again.

The reason the bird goes vertical after it's wet its beak is because the tube at the bottom is no longer fully submerged and the liquid can flow down the tube and the gas shoots back up.


The ambient heat is the source of energy, yes, but the water doesn't need to be colder than the environment.
